Week 2 Discussion Notes

Table of Contents

  • Metric Space Topology

    • Open Balls
    • Open and Closed Sets
    • Adherent Points and Closure

  • Examples

Metric Space Topology

Open Balls

Definition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space. If x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and r>0r > 0r>0, then the open ball of radius rrr centered at xxx is

B(x,r)={y∈X∣d(x,y)<r}.B\p{x, r} = \set{y \in X \mid d\p{x, y} < r}.B(x,r)={y∈X∣d(x,y)<r}.

When talking about topology (i.e., open sets, closed sets, etc.), open balls are like the "atoms." They're going to be the main object used in the definitions and concepts of this section.

Definition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space and E⊆XE \subseteq XE⊆X be a subset.

  1. The interior of EEE, denoted Int⁡E\Int{E}IntE, is the set of points x∈Xx \in Xx∈X where there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that B(x,r)⊆EB\p{x, r} \subseteq EB(x,r)⊆E.
  2. The exterior of EEE, denoted Ext⁡E\Ext{E}ExtE, is the set of points x∈Xx \in Xx∈X where there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that B(x,r)⊆X∖EB\p{x, r} \subseteq X \setminus EB(x,r)⊆X∖E.
  3. The boundary of EEE, denoted ∂E\bd{E}∂E, is the set of points that are not in Int⁡E\Int{E}IntE or Ext⁡E\Ext{E}ExtE.
Example 1.

(Anything dashed is not included in the set.)

Open and Closed Sets

Definition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space and E⊆XE \subseteq XE⊆X be a subset.

  1. EEE is open if for every x∈Ex \in Ex∈E, there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that B(x,r)⊆EB\p{x, r} \subseteq EB(x,r)⊆E.
  2. EEE is closed if its complement X∖EX \setminus EX∖E is open.

One thing to note that is open is not the opposite of closed.

Example 2.

Let (X,d)=(R,∣ ⋅ ∣)\p{X, d} = \p{\R, \abs{\:\cdot\:}}(X,d)=(R,∣⋅∣).

  1. E=(0,1)E = \p{0, 1}E=(0,1) is an open set, but not closed.
    • E=(0,1)=B(12,12)E = \p{0, 1} = B\p{\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}}E=(0,1)=B(21​,21​), so it's an open set. On the other hand, its complement is R∖E=(−∞,0]∪[1,∞)\R \setminus E = \poc{-\infty, 0} \cup \pco{1, \infty}R∖E=(−∞,0]∪[1,∞), which is not open. For example, 111 is not in the interior of R∖E\R \setminus ER∖E.
  2. E=[0,1]E = \br{0, 1}E=[0,1] is a closed set, but not open.
    • Its complement is R∖E=(−∞,0)∪(1,∞)\R \setminus E = \p{-\infty, 0} \cup \p{1, \infty}R∖E=(−∞,0)∪(1,∞), which is open. However, EEE itself is not open since, for example, 000 is not in the interior of EEE.
  3. E=[0,1)E = \pco{0, 1}E=[0,1) is neither open nor closed.
    • EEE is not open since 000 is not in the interior of EEE. On the other hand, its complement R∖E=(−∞,0)∪[1,∞)\R \setminus E = \p{-\infty, 0} \cup \pco{1, \infty}R∖E=(−∞,0)∪[1,∞) is not open, since 111 is not in the interior of X∖EX \setminus EX∖E.
  4. E=RE = \RE=R is both open and closed.
    • EEE is definitely open since every open ball is a subset of EEE, i.e., a subset of the whole space. On the other hand, R∖R=∅\R \setminus \R = \emptysetR∖R=∅, which is open. (This is an example of a vacuous truth. The empty set satisfies the definition of an open set because there are no elements to check the condition on.)

The next two propositions tell you how open/closed sets interact with unions/intersections:

Proposition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space.

  1. ∅,X\emptyset, X∅,X are both open.

  2. If {Ui}i∈I\set{U_i}_{i \in I}{Ui​}i∈I​ is a collection of open sets indexed by III, then its union ⋃i∈IUi\bigcup_{i \in I} U_i⋃i∈I​Ui​ is also open.

    ‘‘Open sets are closed under arbitrary unions."``\text{Open sets are closed under arbitrary unions.}"‘‘Open sets are closed under arbitrary unions."

  3. If U1,…,UnU_1, \ldots, U_nU1​,…,Un​ are open sets, then their intersection U1∩⋯∩UnU_1 \cap \cdots \cap U_nU1​∩⋯∩Un​ is also open.

    ‘‘Open sets are closed under finite intersections."``\text{Open sets are closed under finite intersections.}"‘‘Open sets are closed under finite intersections."
Proposition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space.

  1. ∅,X\emptyset, X∅,X are both closed.

  2. If {Fi}i∈I\set{F_i}_{i \in I}{Fi​}i∈I​ is a collection of closed sets indexed by III, then its union ⋂i∈IFi\bigcap_{i \in I} F_i⋂i∈I​Fi​ is also closed.

    ‘‘Closed sets are closed under arbitrary intersections."``\text{Closed sets are closed under arbitrary intersections.}"‘‘Closed sets are closed under arbitrary intersections."

  3. If F1,…,FnF_1, \ldots, F_nF1​,…,Fn​ are closed sets, then their union F1∪⋯∪FnF_1 \cup \cdots \cup F_nF1​∪⋯∪Fn​ is also closed.

    ‘‘Closed sets are closed under finite unions."``\text{Closed sets are closed under finite unions.}"‘‘Closed sets are closed under finite unions."

The takeaway from these propositions is this:

  1. Open sets interact nicely with unions.
  2. Closed sets interact nicely with intersections.

Adherent Points and Closure

Definition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space and E⊆XE \subseteq XE⊆X be a subset. Then x∈Xx \in Xx∈X (note that xxx is not required to be an element of EEE) is an adherent point of EEE if for every r>0r > 0r>0, we have B(x,r)∩E≠∅B\p{x, r} \cap E \neq \emptysetB(x,r)∩E=∅. The set of adherent points of EEE is called the closure of EEE and is denoted E‾\cl{E}E.

Let's take another look at the definition of an adherent point:

for all r>0, B(x,r)∩E≠∅.\text{for all } r > 0,\ B\p{x, r} \cap E \neq \emptyset.for all r>0, B(x,r)∩E=∅.

We can write it like this:

for all r>0, there exists y∈E such that d(x,y)<r.\text{for all } r > 0, \text{ there exists } y \in E \text{ such that } d\p{x, y} < r.for all r>0, there exists y∈E such that d(x,y)<r.

When you look at this definition, you should be thinking of what happens when rrr is really small. Then you can interpret an adherent point as follows:

‘‘x is an adherent point of E if it can be approximated by elements in E."``x \text{ is an adherent point of } E \text{ if it can be approximated by elements in } E."‘‘x is an adherent point of E if it can be approximated by elements in E."

By quantifying what this means in different ways, you can find different ways of defining an adherent point:

Proposition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space and E⊆XE \subseteq XE⊆X a subset. The following are equivalent:

  1. xxx is an adherent point of EEE.
  2. x∈E‾x \in \cl{E}x∈E.
  3. x∉Ext⁡Ex \notin \Ext{E}x∈/ExtE.
  4. There exists a sequence {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ of elements in EEE such that lim⁡n→∞xn=x\lim_{n\to\infty} x_n = xlimn→∞​xn​=x.
Remark.

To interpret (iii), if x∈Ext⁡Ex \in \Ext{E}x∈ExtE, then xxx is far away from EEE, so it cannot be approximated by elements in EEE. Thus, if x∉Ext⁡Ex \notin \Ext{E}x∈/ExtE, then it's close to EEE, so it's an adherent point.

Examples

Example 3.

Let (X,d)=(R,∣ ⋅ ∣)\p{X, d} = \p{\R, \abs{\:\cdot\:}}(X,d)=(R,∣⋅∣). Show that Q‾=R\cl{\Q} = \RQ​=R.
Solution.

Recall that Q\QQ is dense in R\RR: given any a<ba < ba<b, there exists an element q∈Qq \in \Qq∈Q such that a<q<ba < q < ba<q<b. Rewriting,

a<q<b  ⟺  q∈(a,b),a < q < b \iff q \in \p{a, b},a<q<b⟺q∈(a,b),

so Q\QQ intersects every open interval in R\RR.

To show that Q‾=R\cl{\Q} = \RQ​=R, we need to show that every element x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R is an adherent point of Q\QQ, i.e., for every r>0r > 0r>0, we have B(x,r)∩Q≠∅B\p{x, r} \cap \Q \neq \emptysetB(x,r)∩Q=∅. But B(x,r)=(x−r,x+r)B\p{x, r} = \p{x - r, x + r}B(x,r)=(x−r,x+r), so by density of Q\QQ, we see

B(x,r)∩Q=(x−r,x+r)∩Q≠∅,B\p{x, r} \cap \Q = \p{x - r, x + r} \cap \Q \neq \emptyset,B(x,r)∩Q=(x−r,x+r)∩Q=∅,

so x∈Q‾x \in \cl{\Q}x∈Q​. Thus, Q‾=R\cl{\Q} = \RQ​=R, which was what we wanted to show.
Example 4.

(This example might be a little too hard for this class, but it's a good problem to chew on to test your analysis knowledge.)

Consider the metric space given by

X=ℓ1(N)={absolutely summable real sequences}={an ⁣:N→R | ∑n=1∞∣an∣<∞}d(a,b)=∑n=1∞∣an−bn∣.\begin{aligned} X &= \ell^1\p{\N} \\ &= \set{\text{absolutely summable real sequences}} \\ &= \set{\left. \func{a_n}{\N}{\R} \st \sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{a_n} < \infty \right.} \\ d\p{a, b} &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{a_n - b_n}. \end{aligned}Xd(a,b)​=ℓ1(N)={absolutely summable real sequences}={an​:N→R∣∣​n=1∑∞​∣an​∣<∞}=n=1∑∞​∣an​−bn​∣.​

Let

E={sequences in ℓ1(N) with at most finitely many non-zero terms}.E = \set{\text{sequences in } \ell^1\p{\N} \text{ with at most finitely many non-zero terms}}.E={sequences in ℓ1(N) with at most finitely many non-zero terms}.

Show that EEE is dense in ℓ1(N)\ell^1\p{\N}ℓ1(N), i.e., show E‾=ℓ1(N)\cl{E} = \ell^1\p{\N}E=ℓ1(N).
Solution.

We need to show, given a={an}n∈ℓ1(N)a = \set{a_n}_n \in \ell^1\p{\N}a={an​}n​∈ℓ1(N) and ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, that

B(a,ε)∩E≠∅.B\p{a, \epsilon} \cap E \neq \emptyset.B(a,ε)∩E=∅.

Equivalently, we need to find an element b={bn}n∈Eb = \set{b_n}_n \in Eb={bn​}n​∈E (i.e., an element with at most finitely many non-zero terms) such that

d(a,b)<ε  ⟺  ∑n=1∞∣an−bn∣<ε.d\p{a, b} < \epsilon \iff \sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{a_n - b_n} < \epsilon.d(a,b)<ε⟺n=1∑∞​∣an​−bn​∣<ε.

Let's work backwards to find bbb: given any b∈Eb \in Eb∈E, bbb has only finitely many non-zero terms, so there exists NNN such that bn=0b_n = 0bn​=0 for n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N. Thus,

d(a,b)=∑n=1∞∣an−bn∣=∑n=1N∣an−bn∣+∑n=N+1∞∣an−0∣=∑n=1N∣an−bn∣+∑n=N+1∞∣an∣.\begin{aligned} d\p{a, b} &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{a_n - b_n} \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^N \abs{a_n - b_n} + \sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \abs{a_n - 0} \\ &= \sum_{n=1}^N \abs{a_n - b_n} + \sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \abs{a_n}. \end{aligned}d(a,b)​=n=1∑∞​∣an​−bn​∣=n=1∑N​∣an​−bn​∣+n=N+1∑∞​∣an​−0∣=n=1∑N​∣an​−bn​∣+n=N+1∑∞​∣an​∣.​

To make this quantity small, remember that we have the freedom to choose what each bnb_nbn​ can be. So, we can simply set bn=anb_n = a_nbn​=an​ for 1≤n≤N1 \leq n \leq N1≤n≤N to make the first sum vanish:

d(a,b)=∑n=N+1∞∣an∣.d\p{a, b} = \sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \abs{a_n}.d(a,b)=n=N+1∑∞​∣an​∣.

To finish the proof, it suffices to show that there exists NNN such that the tail of this sum is smaller than ε\epsilonε. But the sequence aaa is absolutely summable, which means that

lim⁡N→∞∑n=N+1∞∣an∣=0.\lim_{N\to\infty} \sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \abs{a_n} = 0.N→∞lim​n=N+1∑∞​∣an​∣=0.

Thus, we can find NNN so that ∑n=N+1∞∣an∣<ε\sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \abs{a_n} < \epsilon∑n=N+1∞​∣an​∣<ε.

Let's put everything together: let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, and let NNN be as in the previous sentence. Set

bn={anif 1≤n≤N,0if n>N.b_n = \begin{cases} a_n & \text{if } 1 \leq n \leq N, \\ 0 & \text{if } n > N. \end{cases}bn​={an​0​if 1≤n≤N,if n>N.​

By construction, b={bn}nb = \set{b_n}_nb={bn​}n​ only has finitely many non-zero terms, so b∈Eb \in Eb∈E. Moreover,

d(a,b)=∑n=1∞∣an−bn∣=∑n=N+1∞∣an∣<ε.\begin{aligned} d\p{a, b} &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{a_n - b_n} \\ &= \sum_{n=N+1}^\infty \abs{a_n} \\ &< \epsilon. \end{aligned}d(a,b)​=n=1∑∞​∣an​−bn​∣=n=N+1∑∞​∣an​∣<ε.​

So b∈B(a,ε)∩Eb \in B\p{a, \epsilon} \cap Eb∈B(a,ε)∩E, and because ε\epsilonε was arbitrary, it follows that a∈E‾a \in \cl{E}a∈E. Since aaa was also arbitrary, we conclude that E‾=ℓ1(N)\cl{E} = \ell^1\p{\N}E=ℓ1(N).
